fields.text: It obviously has emotional reasons. He probably doesn’t even have insomnia at all. Insomnia is when, whatever you do, you’re unable to sleep. But also loneliness, stress, and sadness make you lose sleep pretty easy. When you’re with him, all the distractions leave, and he has a peaceful sleep. A presence in the bed makes you forget about the stressful situations at work or about worries ans duties. When you see someone loved sleeping next to you, you realize that those problems are not worth worrying about. Yes, it can be explained scientifically but it doesn’t have to. It’s just that, when we feel lonely in bed, we lose desire to have a peaceful, healthy sleep. But when somebody is with us, we cherish those moments and sleep along with them. Simple.

EARLY in the day. Why?. Because the early hours of the day are the optimal time for your analytical brain to perform the most complex tasks (in the case of studying, these can be reading, comprehension, application, repetition). Some scientists call this time of day the brain’s peak performance time, and it's roughly 2-4 hours after we wake up. So, for example, if you wake up at 6, your peak times for learning are between 8 and 10 a.m. You can extend this time until midday so that you cover the most important concepts by lunchtime.

Used cars aren’t just for people who don’t have money to buy brand new ones. You can get a used car with 20,000 miles which is $10,000 cheaper. You can get an old car at $3000 and keep it for 3–4 years and then resell it for $1500. The more expensive the car is, the more money it will lose over time. I’ve seen a great car (Honda Civic) at 8500 euros in Germany and it had 46,000 km. It was as new at half the price (from 2009). Used cars can definitely be a smart way to save money and/or change cars frequently without wasting too much money.

According to the Global peace Index 2017, Iceland is the most chilled country. No pun intended. The index, developed by the Institute of Economics and Peace, is a ranking of 162 countries based on 22 different indicators including level of violent crime, relations with neighbouring countries, the absence of war, contribution to U. N peace keeping mission, schooling…etc.. The lower the GPI index score , the more peaceful the country is.

Read, read, read. One of the easiest things you can do to learn English faster is to read as much as you can. Read things all the time. This will make your vocabulary better and it will also help you learn grammar and slang. Read comics. An easy option, if you don't want to read children's books, is to read comic books or comics instead. You can buy many English language comic books in bookstores and online, or you can read free comics online (these are usually called webcomics).Read books you've read before. You can also read a book you have read before. If you already know a little bit about what happens, then you will have an easier time guessing and understanding the words. Read the newspaper. Newspapers are a good way to learn the basics of a language, because they usually have very good grammar and are written to be easy to understand. You can find online versions of many good English language newspapers, like the New York Times or The Guardian.

You Should Only Use the Charger That Came With Your Device. Modern smartphones use USB chargers, which are standardized. As long as a USB charger can provide enough power, you can use it to charge your smartphone or any other device that supports USB charging. Feel free to plug your phone into a more powerful charger. Your phone will only draw as much power as it needs from the charger, so it shouldn’t become damaged. In fact, your phone may even charge faster with a more powerful charger. You could plug your phone into a less-powerful charger, too — it just wouldn’t charge as fast, or it may not charge at all if the charger isn’t powerful enough

No, staying in USA without authorization is not a felony (in layman’s term: crime). It is obviously a violation of the law —just like driving above the speed limit— but it’s a misdemeanor at worst. It only becomes a felony if you reenter after the court has you removed (deported).Defendants in purely immigration cases are not entitled to counsel (a lawyer) at government’s expense, because immigration is a civil matter. Otherwise the 6th amendment of the constitution would apply, because it guarantees the right to counsel for criminal proceedings.

My answer is: because Prisoner of Azkaban was the first book when the series showed its potential. The first two books were simple as compared with the five to follow. As you know, Rowling continued in that direction, culminating in the two mysteries in the last book: where are those Horcruxes? And, what is the truth behind the Deathly Hallows?. I have Tourette’s with Coprolalia. I can’t hold my tics in and don’t know they are coming. Tourette Syndrome is very exhausting as your body is always moving and you are always making noises and saying things. One thing I here often is “Do you tic in your sleep?” Yes I do, so you don’t sleep very well and wake others up in the house. I have hurt myself from my tics where I have dislocated parts of my body, broken my bones, hurt discs in my neck, gave myself corneal abrasions from scratching my eye, broken teeth, and a lot more. At times it is hard to walk and do simple tasks with tics. Medication does help a little bit. There is not much to say about Coprolalia except that it is hard to go out with it because sometime parents will say to you get way from my child as they don’t want there child to hear bad stuff. I don’t just say bad words but for example around when the election for president I would have said “Who did you vote for?” This is also known as Coprolalia as this is not socially appropriate.  I try to spread as much awareness as possible. If you have any other questions I would love to try to answer them.

The ratio of the mass of any man made object to that of the Earth is so tiny that the effect is negligible. It is like asking if you would be knocked over if a gnat bumped into you - but much more extreme. Te mass gain from infalling space dust is far greater than that lost from rocket launches - many tons per day. Most of the mass of the rocket launch falls back to the Earth within minutes. Most satellites fall back within years. The mass which has permanently left the Earth probably amounts to a hundred tons or so - two or three day’s worth of meteorite arrivals.

No, Wikileaks is not derived from Wikipedia. Wikileaks derives its information from leaks of previously unpublished secret information. Wikipedia is an encyclopaedia, a tertiary source derived from secondary and sometimes primary sources but published, not secret sources. Wikileaks’ information is not going to be derived from Wikipedia, though it is possible that some of Wikipedia’s content is derived from Wikileaks, either directly or indirectly via press reports.

It is not possible to fly a plane in space. Air moving over the wings is what give it lift and allows it to manoeuvre. Air is also required by all jet and propeller propulsion systems. In space, there is no air so none of these work. Instead, space travel relies on rockets. A rocket carries its own air or oxygen supply so can operate outside the earth's atmosphere. Of course, it is possible to use rockets to put a plane into space then use the wings to safely land after re-entering the atmosphere. Such operations were rather routine until just a few years ago.

When GPS was first being developed, some of the engineers were skeptical of the relativistic corrections, and so they did indeed include a mechanism by which the correction could be turned on and off from the ground even after the satellites were in orbit. They saw that turning the correction “off” led to errors in the system, and so they left it “on” after that. I doubt that modern GPS satellites have such a “switch” built into them, as the doubts of the engineers have already been settled.

It’s not weird at all. Bring a book, a newspaper or a tablet to read, or sit at the bar. I promise that no one will care or notice what you’re doing. And if they do, so what? Why do you care what strangers think of you?I go out to eat by myself fairly regularly. My boyfriend lives far away from me and my work schedule means that I’m off when a lot of my friends are working, and vice versa. So if I want to go out to eat, this can often mean doing it by myself. Dopamine levels and the structure of dopamine receptors underlie this temperament difference between Introverts and Extraverts (On the Psychobiology of Personality). In broad strokes, Introverts have high baseline levels of cognitive stimulation and arousal even at rest and thus are constantly trying to avoid any additional visual and social stimuli. So when they're trying to concentrate, nearby noises or people are additional stimuli that becomes distracting and pushes them over their optimal level of arousal. Extraverts, on the other hand, are at a constant arousal deficit and require extra stimuli to compensate and bring them to their optimal level. So they seek out places with lots of people, loud music, or interesting visuals.

You can’t prove a concept does not exist in reality. You may be able to disprove specific claims of god, on a case by case basis. First and foremost, “god” needs to be very clearly defined… like anything that is being debated or studied. Take unicorns… no one can prove to a court of law that they don’t exist (anywhere, in the infinite universe). Or even that they didn’t once live somewhere on Earth. Or that one didn’t. I mean, a horse and a narwhal could have hooked up, once or twice. Even if you could inventory and account for every atom in the universe (and say no unicorn fossils exist), evidence is lost to time. Most gods are claimed to be supernatural, that is beyond science, beyond nature. So this is the wrong question… as a society we need to DEMAND that EVERYONE provide evidence for ANY CLAIM being made. Especially when the issue is a matter of public policy. We should ONLY accept facts as a basis for establishing truth. In other words, god is not proven… your job is done. The believers need to prove it, or accept it’s a matter of faith, and hence has no place in public policy.

Almost all animals alive today are successfully evolved, apart from a few things like the tuatara which has been largely left behind by evolution because it lives on a sheltered, isolated island. Some species do get shafted because conditions change suddenly and more rapidly than they can adapt to, usually because some human introduced cats into their environment - but most were well-adapted to the conditions which existed *before* that sudden change. Nor are we the most successfully evolved animal, since we tend to destroy our own environment and then starve. The best adapted mammal is either the brown rat or the house mouse, and the best-adapted animal overall will be whatever the most common species of nematode is.

Category theory is not considered controversial in any way. It is a fundamental part of mathematics since the 1950’s. The language of category theory has become part of standard mathematical discourse even among mathematicians who don't use the results of category theory itself. Few mathematicians employ the Yoneda lemma, but every mathematician understands what “functor” means. The only reasons I can imagine why you'd think there's any controversy are:You may have heard the term “abstract nonsense”. This is a light-hearted, tongue-in-cheek reference to the universal aspect of category theory. It doesn't signify a controversy regarding either the validity or the significance of any category-theoretic argument. It takes some care to set up the set-theoretic foundations of category theory, which naively deals with proper classes such as “the category of all groups”. This isn't hard to do, and doesn't leave the theory in a foundational crisis.

I share my van. I share my computer mouse. I share my tent. I do not share my wife. The difference between my wife and these other things is these other things are my property. My wife is not. My wife has other lovers. But I’m not “sharing” her; she is choosing to have other lovers, and I’m totally okay with that. If people choose to be married but not monogamous, yes, that’s totally okay, as long as all the parties involved are on board with it. But I don’t like thinking about it in terms of “sharing” people. Language matters; the language we use both shapes and communicates the way we see the world. I don’t “share” people because I don’t think people are property.

Many people have a down cycle after lunch. You can eat a light lunch which will help. That way your body isn’t processing a heavy load of carbs and not as much energy is spent in the digestion of your meal. You can also build in a small amount of exercise: stretching, a short walk. Exercise helps digestion and helps improve your overall energy level. You can also deliberately set a timer for a work period. There is a method called the Pomodoro method you can check out which lets you set a clock and at the end of that time, you stop your work, rest for 5 minutes and then reset the clock. This method has been scientifically proven to help people be more productive.

There is a cutoff duration of 17 hours, races completed after that time are not considered. The person who completes the race within 17 hours is given the title ‘Ironman’. That is correct, yes. If you’re not allowed to do it, you can’t ask someone else to. Shabbat is supposed to be a day off for everyone — even your animals — and so it’s not fair to ask someone outright to do something that you can’t do. Of course, there’s a way around this, and it’s to ask by implication. Not allowed: “I can’t turn on the light switch because I’m Jewish, can you?”Allowed: “boy, it sure is dark in here! And since I’m Jewish, I’m not allowed to turn on the switch. That switch, the one right over there.”This distinction isn’t in the Torah, but rather the Talmud (also called “Oral Law”), the commentaries and discussion on the laws in the Torah. Traditional Jews believe that the Oral Law also comes directly from God, and was simply written down much later, and so give it the full weight of divine authority. Liberal Jews, generally, do not believe this about the Talmud (for some, not even the Torah!), and therefore do not feel bound by its rulings.

Trump is not ending the Visa Waiver Program. Trump is ending the Visa Interview Waiver Program. Therefore, aliens who require visas in order to enter the US will now have to attend in-person interviews. However, aliens who do not require visas, such as most citizens of VWP countries, will be unaffected. Note that it’s not Trump’s fault that a citizen of a VWP country who is also a citizen of, say, Syria, requires a visa to visit the US. That restriction was enacted by Congress during Obama’s term.

Obsessive-compulsive disorder, or OCD, is an anxiety disorder that generally causes extreme discomfort. Sufferers are often riddled with persistent and recurrent impulses, thoughts and images that are unwanted. According to the National Institute for Mental Health, OCD affects more than 2million adults in the United States. Severe cases of OCD can cause an extreme amount of distress, and the disorder can dramatically interfere with a person’s daily life. Sufferers of OCD are generally very anxious and emotional. They display many non- OCD symptoms, such as signs of depression, excessive worry,extreme tension, and the constant feeling that nothing is ever right. Aside from the obvious compulsive behaviors a person with OCD displays, there are no physical signs of this disorder; however, a person with OCD can develop physical problems. For example, a person with a germ obsession may wash their hands so much that the skin on them becomes red, raw and painful. A person with OCD may experience multiple short-term effects, including the inability to function as a contributing member of society, difficulties at school or work,or trouble maintaining friendships or romantic relationships. The long-term effects of OCD generally develop due to the poor quality of life that most extreme sufferers have. Long-term effects include depression, constant anxiety and an increased risk of substance abuse.

One of the best ways of dealing with these is to be proactive. Make sure your child isn't hungry, thirsty or tired. If you go out, make sure you have snacks and drink, and do not go out at nap time. Offer food before the meltdown, hand her a drink, put her down for a nap before she gets over tired. This will pass, but ONLY if it never works. By that I mean, never give in to the tantrum. If you are out somewhere and she starts, calmly pick her up. Say this is not a good way to behave, carry her back to your car and go home. If that means leaving a full cart of groceries, so be it. If she does it at home, ignore her, but keep her safe. By that I mean do not let her throw things or crash into things. I used to sit on the floor and pull my child into my arms, my legs over hers, my arms crossed over her arms. I wasn't holding her down, I was holding her safe. I didn't talk to her during this, stayed calm, and I kept my head up so she couldn't head butt me. Once she realizes that tantrums will not get her what she wants, she will stop, and it probably won't even take too long. I had five children, but only had to deal with this a few times. I think the older ones told the younger ones to forget it, as it didn't work. With children, you can say no 99 times. If you say yes once, the child will only learn that it worked once, and will keep trying the behavior you don't like. Be strong, be consistent and stay calm. My kids would sometimes yell, I hate you! Baking soda and baking powder are both leaveners used in baking, but they are chemically different. The easiest way to explain it is that baking soda is a base—it’s alkaline. As other respondents have pointed out, there is no Queen of England. I will, however, assume you are referring to Queen Elizabeth II, the Queen of the United Kingdom and Head of the Commonwealth. Had her father not become King, she would have remained Princess Elizabeth of York in the same way that the current Duke of York’s daughters are Princess Beatrice of York and Princess Eugenie of York. In recent times it has become more usual for such ducal names to be adopted as surnames in certain, less formal, situations. For example as Charles is the Prince of Wales, his sons would be Prince William (or Henry - Harry’s real name) of Wales, but when they entered the armed forces, and probably, also at school, they were known as William Wales and Harry Wales. The Queen doesn't need a surname, who else in the world could anyone mean when referring to Queen Elizabeth the second?

Catholics believe that the authority to administer the Church of Jesus Christ and its ordinances (such as baptism and the sacrament) was passed down from Jesus to Peter and the Apostles to others and later Bishops and Popes and Cardinals and Priests in an unbroken succession. Protestants believe that the authority was lost somewhere along the way because the Catholic Church had become corrupt and was no longer teaching the pure Gospel that Jesus had taught. The dealt with the need for God’s authority by developing the doctrine of the “Priesthood of all believers,” or a Universal priesthood. That is the core difference - other doctrinal differences generally stem from this central disagreement coupled with the differences in Biblical interpretation that divide all churches and sects.

It is impossible to get work-life balance because balance is something that you do, not something that you have. Heat is kinetic energy, the energy manifest in the molecular vibration of molecules. The faster the molecules vibrate, the higher the temperature gets, the more energy available to do work. Like balls on a pool table, the hot, fast moving molecules bump into the slower ones transferring some kinetic energy and raising the temperature. If you store heat directly say by heating up a block of steel so it’s red hot then dropping it into water thus boiling the water to make steam and drive a piston, you have converted the kinetic (heat) energy in the hot steel into work. Energy is the ability to do work so heat is energy. The concepts of work, energy and heat are interrelated but not intuitive so it’s understandable that you might have some confusion about what is what. You are about to have an Aha! moment, keep going…
For any object that starts at rest, it takes infinite energy to reach the speed of light. That's more energy than we have in the observable universe. So we can't even reach the speed of light.

This is not what you want to hear... But I suggest backing up your data, gathering your install media for any programs you want to keep, and then re-installing the OS from scratch. I mean a full re-format and install. This is not me being a jerk; I try to do this at least once a year on my production systems. At the end of the day, there is no optimization like a fresh install. And, as @Ivan said, ZEALOUSLY try to keep the garbage off the system for as long as you can. If you don't need it, don't install it. Here's the thing: Windows has gotten a LOT better about isolating installations properly and cleaning up after uninstallations... but at the end of the day careless developers are careless developers -- big software houses and small. These "artifacts" add up, and that -- as well as unnecessarily running background processes and settings that you may have never intended to change -- are what causes the system to become sluggish. The best way to guard against this is to pay attention to what you are installing and, even then, to install "responsibly". My golden rule? Uninstall anything that you have the media for and that you don't use at least once a month. And do your best to stay away from the pirated stuff.

The law in many western countries considers marriage to be a particular form of economic union. Most property acquired during the marriage accrues to the benefit of both spouses, as do their debts. If the marriage ends, each spouse is entitled to 50% of the value acquired during marriage (less any debts acquired during that time). Many jurisdictions now have no fault divorce, which means it doesn't matter why the marriage ended, nor does a court attempt to assign blame. It's over, and the assets of the marriage get divided up. And since the law applies equally to everyone, wives are treated no differently than husbands. So the cheating husband doesn't get any more or less either.

There is a lot of time available for reading in everyone's life. It's just a matter of making a decision that you are going to read rather than watch TV, play on the internet, garden, go to a movie, have dinner with a friend, or be with your children. Time -- and our inability to create any more hours in any day -- is the constant for every human being. So reading has to assume an importance in your life when compared to other competing demands. Since reading requires concentration -- it's practically impossible to multi-task if you are absorbed in a good book -- there will be times that are better suited to reading than others. Lying in bed at night is a traditional time for reading. If you commute on public transit, have a lunch hour without work to be done or friends to visit -- all good times. You can also set aside a time when you tell friends and family that it's your reading time -- then protect it and refuse alternative offers. In our over-scheduled lives, with crushing demands from all directions, always make time for yourself.

An abstraction can be applied to any specific circumstances that fit. Abstracting from many (many) specific examples, is computationally (brain-time) costly, probably on the order of 100x more difficult, and may lead to improper understandings and principles. People taught by example will therefore tend to fail to apply the principles to new problems they haven’t seen before. People taught abstractions, will tend apply the abstraction to new circumstances, yielding correct solutions (solutions that work). Otherwise, class time is limited. Never believe you won’t use it again; if you believe you won’t use it again, you probably won’t, but if you learn it, you’re likely to move up to jobs and conditions that require it (and much, much more complex knowledge).

It would be too costly, but there is a bigger reason not to launch nuclear waste into space: safety. Think about how many launch disasters there have been (Challenger) compared to how many overall launches. The failure rate may be good enough when the only lives at stake are those who willingly went aboard, but when there is a chance that an explosion in the atmosphere will disperse nuclear waste over a wide area, the failure rate must be much, much lower. Considering the volume of nuclear waste that would have to be sent up, there would have to be a lot more launches, which means the failure rate would have to be lower still in order to be publicly acceptable.

It depends on when the student is sleeping. Often they sleep in afternoon classes after they have eaten lunch. Eating releases a cascade of hormones to help metabolize food, including serotonin, which can make you sleepy. Also the kinds of foods that a student eats will have differing effects. Proteins especially make you sleepy, but also foods like bananas release melatonin, which can make you sleepy. It's not all bad either. At least one study has shown that a post lunch nap increases alertness. Perhaps teenagers should have a scheduled nap time after lunch like some primary school children do. If you can't stop students from sleeping in afternoon classes, then maybe we should start planning for that entirely predictable effect.

In addition to the "humans and apes evolved from a common ancestor" answer, which is the key point, there's another misconception to tease out here: that evolution is a series of "X is replaced by Y" steps. It isn't. All that's required for a new variant of a species to emerge from an evolutionary process is for that variant to occur and survive over time. That can happen whether the ancestor species sticks around or not. What makes this non-obvious is that most species don't survive long-term; the vast, vast majority of species that have existed on Earth are extinct now. So if you look back, chances are that any given ancestor of any given modern species is long gone. But that's not necessarily because it was replaced per se. Rather, it probably coexisted for quite a long time with its descendant, gradually dying out for whatever reason (possibly, but not necessarily, including being outcompeted for scarce resources -- it's definitely true that competition plays a big role) until only the more recent species remained. Viewed from afar, this looks a bit like "species A transformed into species B" but that's just a conceptual shortcut, not the actual mechanism at work.

There is no known proof of Goldbach’s conjecture. There’s a conjecture known as Goldbach’s weak conjecture, which states that every odd number greater than 5 is the sum of three primes. In 1937, Vinogradov proved that this is true for all sufficiently large odd numbers, and in 2013 Helfgott proved it completely, by lowering the threshold of “sufficiently large” to about 10271027, which is small enough to already have been covered by computer verifications.

The best thing you can do is read in English everyday - read outside of your interests in particular.  Read newspapers and magazines that are known for their quality (Wall Street Journal, New York Times, The Economist, among many others).  Reading well-written material is one of the best ways to improve your own writing because it exposes you to expressions and sentence constructions that are generally acceptable in written English.  It will develop your ear for the language so you can learn to distinguish between what sentence constructions work and what sounds awkward (even if it might be grammatically correct). Depending on what you need to write, supplement generalist reading with readings in your field (or read items that are similar to the things you want to produce yourself) to see how people in the same field use written English.

Because a lot of American food culture comes from the schedule on a farm. Chores like milking cows would have to be completed early in the morning, before working in the fields. (And again in the evening.) Eggs, like milk, were collected in the morning. Served at breakfast, both would be at their freshest. Breakfast was eaten before heading out for a day of long physical labor. It was a meal that needed to provide energy, but not be complicated to prepare so early in the day. Omelets take more time than the same number of eggs scrambled, but they are not too demanding. Likewise grits, oatmeal and pancakes.

It's a hold-over from the early days of the Cold War when Europe was still in recovery from WWII and the U.S. was the prevailing democratic superpower. The President of the United States, as chief executive of the superpower and its military, was thus described as the "leader of the free world," basically by default of the weakness of the other democratic powers. Even as they recovered and rebuilt their military and economic strength, the U.S. was undeniably the most powerful military force for democratic nations during the Cold War. The descriptor might have fallen out of favor entirely after the fall of the Soviet Union and the rise of a multi-polar world, but it got a spike in popularity after 9/11 as the U.S. took the lead in the Global War on Terrorism. Cool chart from Google Ngram showing the popularity of the phrase's use in publications over time (note the spike in 1963/1964 and decline in popularity through the Vietnam War):

You get stronger by giving your body a reason to get stronger.  That is to say, you present it with a stimulus that the body responds to (if you have enough recovery factors eg. food, sleep etc) by getting stronger.  Liftings weights is one of the best ways to do this, but it is not the only way. You could, for example, use bodyweight exercises.  No weights needed there, at least at first (once you get really strong you need add weight).  You could train as a gymnast (though this will involve weights almost certainly, though I guess it doesn't have to) or a ballet dancer.  That'll get you stronger. If you want to know the basic principles of getting stronger, you could do a lot worse than buy the excellent book Starting Strength by Mark Rippetoe.

To me, it makes more sense to go with a procedure which is permanent rather than something which is temporary, such as waxing, trimming, shaving etc. The more ideal option would be permanent hair reduction through laser, or electrolysis. In both cases, the hair will not recur after the completion of the procedure.*Electrolysis is a bit more protracted than laser, and can be painful, as it involves passing a mild electric shock through each hair (individually) so as to destroy the hair follicle. On the other hand, laser hair removal entails a high pulse laser beam being directed at the follicle of the root, causing its destruction and thereby preventing hair from sprouting again. Laser removal is almost painless and might be accompanied by redness and soreness of skin, at a mild level. Both procedures ideally require multiple sittings before they are completed satisfactorily. Both methods are perfectly safe to be used on pubic as well as underarm regions of your body. The one catch with laser is - it works best on skin of light complexion and hair which is thicker and darker, than vice versa, while the same does not apply to electrolysis. Regarding hair removal creams, they may or may not cause darkening - it depends upon the chemical composition of the product, and your reaction to it. Some people attempt to counteract the darkening using hydroquinone or mequinol (with renin) subsequent to darkening (both chemicals used for tropical depigmentation).I think I've addressed the issue adequately. *In case of electrolysis, there will be no recurrence of hair, but in case of laser hair removal, there are minor chances of hair recurrence, especially triggered by hormone changes, among other factors. Please consult with a qualified expert dermatologist before making a final decision as to which procedure you wish to undergo.

You should sell something for profit. It really is that simple, but it definitely isn’t that easy (at least not most of the time). Entrepreneurs find opportunities to fulfill the needs or wants of other people for a profit. This means that you first need to discover an opportunity, which you can do through research, then figure out the cost of the product or service that will fulfill the underlying need (by doing some more research), then calculating a price at which people would be willing to buy it, and give you enough profit to grow the business. In some ways being an entrepreneur is really just about having a conversation with a specific group of people (your market). You first find out what they need, and when you deliver a solution they may or may not like it. If they don’t like it you go back to the drawing board and figure out better ways to solve the need they may have. If they do like your solution, your task it so make sure that they keep on buying from you. So there it is - start by asking a specific group of people what they need, then try and solve that problem at a worthwhile profit.

The term you’re looking for is spiritualist, though you could specify atheistic spiritualist if you want. Spiritualism is the belief that unmeasurable spirits exist in addition to the measurable natural world as two separate domains, which interact within living things, which are both natural and spiritual. It is directly contrasted with naturalism, which posits either that no spiritual realm exists, or that no spiritual realm needs to exist. Many people make the mistake of assuming naturalism to be opposed to theism, but there are naturalistic theists in the world, particularly in less modernised nations. These are people who believe a god exists in the natural world, in apex predator forms, as a human ruler, and/or even in inanimate objects like the earth. Ancient Aztecs were naturalistic theists, who worshipped a pantheon of natural gods, which include the sun, moon, king, and famously, Quetzalcoatl, the avian god. Incidentally, one thing they got right was that birds and reptiles are related… something only discovered centuries later to be true through fossil records, though this could simply have been a lucky guess… or an unrecorded observation of an ancient fossil of a transitional species. Most naturalistic theist beliefs have been supplanted by modern science, while spiritualism, due to its nature, is impossible by definition to disprove. Thus most modern religions that persist today are spiritualist in form, though spiritualistic atheism is also similarly impossible to disprove.
